author: Jack Williams
title: Incredible pictures show Kawah Ijen volcano spewing BLUE molten lava
text:
Molten lava is red hot - so why is this volcano spewing out liquid that's BLUE?
These otherworldly images appear to show molten lava glowing a vibrant blue shade.
The phenomenon is found at the Kawah Ijen crater, on the island of Java, Indonesia.
READ MORE: Amazing drone photography captures awe-inspiring Iceland from the sky Caters These otherworldly images appear to show molten lava that is glowing a vibrant shade of BLUE at the Kawah Ijen crater, on the island of Java, Indonesia
But the effect is actually caused by sulphuric gas, which works its way to the surface, where it is heated by the lava flow.
Temperatures inside the crater reach more than 500C causing the gas to ignite.
The ignited gas burns with a blue colour, with some appearing to form a liquid, flowing over the surface of the lava.
Caters Glow: The blue effect is actually caused by sulphuric gas
British photographer Reuben Wu travelled to the remote location in July, snapping stunning pictures of the 'Blue Fire Crater' as it is sometimes called.
Reuben, from Liverpool, said: "The view was quite overwhelming and I was very close to the fumaroles at the time.
"This meant that I was inside a thick cloud of sulphur gas and it was very difficult to breathe - even through my respirator - let alone take a picture."
Caters Blue river: The snaps were taken by British photographer Reuben Wu
This phenomenon can be witnessed best during darkness, as during the day there is an appearance of a reddish liquid.
Reuben became aware of the location in 2009 while on a research trip in Jakarta, but he did not visit the crater and nearby Mount Bromo until this year.
The keen snapper, 40, who lives in Chicago, Illinois, USA, visited the crater at sunset and on the two-hour hike documented the stunning surrounding areas.
Caters Awe-inspiring: Reuben travelled to the remote location in July
He added: "I wanted to show not just the look of the blue fire, but also the environment it exists in.
"The crater is stained yellow from the sulphur deposits and the acid lake is bright green and steaming, so it wasn't just the molten sulphur which I wanted to photograph, but the entire scene of very strange forces of nature.
"The most amazing thing is that the fire is really blue - I didn't change the colour."
